Package ds.time

This package describes objects that meaure 24-hour time and that measure the elapsed time for a process to execute.

See:
          Description

Class Summary
Time24 An instance of the class stores time in hour and minute units where hour is in the range 0 to 23 and minute is in the range 0 to 59.
Timing An instance of the class acts like a stop watch for measuring the time required to execute a process; time is measured in seconds from start to stop using millisecond intervals from the system clock.
 

Package ds.time Description

This package describes objects that meaure 24-hour time and that measure the elapsed time for a process to execute.

The Time24 class describes the time of day in 24-hour units without the familar "AM, PM" suffix. For instance 22:30 corrsponds to 10:30 PM and 7:15 corresponds to 7:15 AM.

The class is used extensively in the book to illustrate important object-oriented conception and data structure attributes. The Time24 class has methods that illustrate the Comparable, Clonable, and Serializable interfaces.

For most of the searching and sorting algorithms in the book, we are able to describe their runtime efficiency using Big-O notation. This gives a theoretical measure of the efficiency of the algorithm in terms of the size of the array or collection. With the Timing class, we can create objects that measure the duration of a process much like a stop watch measures the duration of a run. Using a timing object to measure an algorithms execution for a large data set, we can gain an empirical measure of the runtime efficiency of the algorithm. Timing class object use millisecond intervals from the system clock to measure elapsed time for a process from start to stop. Time is measured in seconds.
